sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Populist Movement. Farmers Organize (1890s). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Emma, age 16, Kansas farm daughter, 1896.

I'm Emma, sixteen years old, and I live on a wheat farm in Kansas. My family works from sunrise to sunset planting, tending, and harvesting wheat. We work harder every year. Yet every year we sink deeper into debt.
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Emma, sixteen years old, and I live on a wheat farm in Kansas.

sections.narration: Farmers across the country are organizing. The Farmers' Alliance starts in Texas and spreads across the South and West. By 1890, it has over a million members. The Alliance holds meetings in schoolhouses and churches.
sections.key_takeaway: Farmers across the country are organizing.

sections.narration: In 1892, the Farmers' Alliance forms a political party: the People's Party, also called the Populist Party. At the founding convention in Omaha, Nebraska, we adopt a platform demanding sweeping reforms. The preamble is radical: "We meet in the midst of a nation brought to the verge of moral, political, and material ruin. Corruption dominates the ballot-box, the Legislatures, the Congress...
sections.key_takeaway: In 1892, the Farmers' Alliance forms a political party: the People's Party, also called the Populist Party.

sections.narration: 1896. The presidential election focuses on the money question: gold standard or free silver? Republicans nominate William McKinley, who supports the gold standard. He's backed by banks, corporations, and Eastern financial interests.
visuals: Chapter title: The Cross of Gold

sections.narration: November 1896. McKinley wins. He carries the Northeast, Midwest, and urban areas. Bryan carries the South and rural West.
In this lesson, we explored The Populist Movement through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Populist Party, William Jennings Bryan, Cross of Gold Speech, Free Silver.
